awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Development of a high-precision, rapid curing technology for printed electronics on low-temperature surfaces with off-the-shelf inks
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation (PFI) project is to introduce ways to prepare printed electronics. The global market for printed electronics is growing exponentially with new applications identified daily in the automotive and biomedical fields. The majority of existing applications undergo long preparation process, known as curing, in external ovens at high temperatures. This results in significant time and energy costs, while the high temperature requirement limits the range of materials that can be used without undergoing melting, warping, or other damage during the heating process. A fast curing technology that focuses heat can reduce costs, enabling the manufacturing of electronics on flexible, colder surfaces.  The ultimate goal is to launch a start-up company offering fast curing solutions to meet market needs in a variety of industries, ranging from automotive to wearables.

The proposed project will accelerate the design, development and commercialization of a fast, in-line curing system to address functionalization of printed electronics on low-temperature surfaces. To realize this technology advancement, the intellectual merit of the proposed work focuses on (1) determining performance and testing requirements for a class of identified printed electrical devices and material combinations (ink/substrate), (2) deriving new knowledge of in-line curing methods and system design in the context of key success metrics, (3) determining the correlation between material properties, device requirements, and curing process parameters, and (4) developing a prototype in-line curing system that meets critical design and process specifications. To mitigate the risks associated with the proposed project, the team aims to provide early proof-of-concept and characterization tests to demonstrate feasibility, incorporate design redundancy through the investigation of two curing methods, develop strategic partnerships with industry experts to discuss technical hurdles and innovative solutions, and conduct experimental testing to enable statistical analysis of process throughput, yield, and robustness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Advancements in manufacturing have become more critical over the past several years as the paradigm for ubiquitous data collection across a diverse range of applications has evolved. Recent technology advancements from wearable sensing to autonomous vehicles have demonstrated the need for integrated sensing modalities that enable real-time data collection in different environments, from various surfaces, and with varying levels of fidelity. Importantly, additive manufacturing (AM) can plan an important role in fabricating the sensing technology necessary to achieve this transformation. Current research and commercial advancements have been focused on new ink developments that can be used to meet functional requirements of the printed integrated sensors. Additionally, process modifications to enable faster or more reliable printing have emerged. Despite the improvements to the process dynamics and material interactions, a critical aspect of the functional performance of these printed devices stems from the curing process, an often over-looked step in the AM process that many assume to be standard.

The objective of this work was to advance the state of knowledge in high-precision curing of conductive materials directly onto functional surfaces. The research conducted during this award has provided a pathway towards understanding the complex interactions that occur during the curing process that determine the curing outcome, and more importantly the performance of the device. New curing approaches that used laser-based and localized hot-air curing methodologies were investigated. Interactions driven by the timing, directionality, resolution, and intensity of the localized curing technique were identified and then used to inform performance capabilities. Modified printing modalities were explored to better understand the relationship between the printing process, curing process, and overall performance of the printed device. The outcome of these investigations has led to several submitted patent applications that will be licensed by a startup company from the University. The postdoctoral researcher and students associated with this project have engaged in activities that advanced their understanding of technology innovation and commercialization, and provided a competitive skill set that has set them apart from their peers when entering the workforce.  

 

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2021
Modified by: Kira Barton
